DeregistrationReasonOtherText: EPA has administratively marked this facility as 'Closed'.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention Policies
The Rolls-Royce Test Cell has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the propane system. The facility policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent the foreseeable release of regulated substances. 
Employees and contractors at the Rolls-Royce Test Cell facility are subject to an up-to-date training program. The program includes on the job hands-on training. Competency is assessed through oral tests, demonstration, and observation. 
In accordance with state and federal guidelines, the Rolls-Royce Test Cell facility must perform a Process Hazard Analysis every five (5) years (last performed on January 19, 2018) and a Compliance Audit every three (3) years. From these evaluations, preventative and mitigative measures were identified at the facility. These include, but are not limited to: Vents, Relief Valves, Check Valves, Manual Shutoffs, Automatic Shutoffs, Alarms and Procedures, Backup Pump and Grounding Equipment.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
The primary activity at the facility is industrial engine testing. The largest vessel storing propane in the system is the Propane Storage Tank. The total inventory of the flammable propane mixture at the facility is 125,100 lbs., reported as 130,000 lbs., which classifies the process as a CalARP Program 3 process, which is regulated by Cal/OHSA and OSHA PSM regulations as well. Propane is considered hazardous because it is explosive and exposure to this substance can cause skin burns, frostbite and asphyxiation.
The facility uses process area monitors to detect and identify if propane is present. If an individual has been exposed to propane the following guidelines corresponding to the type of exposure should be followed:
¿Inhalation - Remove person to fresh air.
o improve safety are listed as recommendations in the January 2018 PHA Report.

If not breathing, administer artificial respiration. If breathing is difficult, administer oxygen. Obtain prompt medical attention immediately.
¿Ingestion - Ingestion of propane is not a likely route of industrial exposure.
¿Skin contact - Immediately remove all contaminated clothing. Rinse skin with lukewarm water and shower if necessary. Call a poison center or physician immediately.
¿Eye contact - Rinse cautiously with water for several minutes. Remove contact lenses if present and continue rinsing. Call a poison center or physician immediately.
¿Leak/Gas fire - Do not extinguish unless leak can be stopped safely. Eliminate all ignition sources if safe to do so. 
To reduce the chance of exposure, fire or explosion, or reduce the impact if an exposure happens the facility has installed a sprinkler system and deluge system in the test cell as mitigation measures.

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary
Scenario Description: Per the CalARP Regulations, one worst-case release scenario has been defined for the propane system. The worst-case release scenario demonstrated the outcome of the Propane Storage Tank losing its entire inventory of propane (125,100 lbs.), which resulted in a radius of concern of 0.4 miles in which the propane reaches a distance to the overpressure endpoint of 1 pound per square inch (psi). This release has the potential to reach 0 housing units and 0 people based on 2010 U.S Census data. Additional details can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation. 

Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary
Scenario Description: Per the CalARP Regulations, one alternative release scenario has been defined for the propane system. The alternative release scenario was determined by evaluating the most likely scenario that could result in a significant hazard. For this facility, the alternative release scenario involves the puncture of the outside of the Propane Storage Tank by an external projectile, resulting in a hole with a 1 inc

h diameter. This scenario creates a radius of concern of 0.2 miles in which the propane reaches a distance to the overpressure endpoint of 1 psi. The release has the potential to reach 0 housing units and 0 people based on 2010 U.S Census data. Additional details can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Prevention Steps
As part of the implementation of CalARP Program 3, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by the facility to manage process safety issues associated with the use of propane. Prevention Program 3 elements are listed below:
¿19 CCR § 2760.1 Process Safety Information (PSI)
¿19 CCR § 2760.2 Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
¿19 CCR § 2760.3 Operating Procedures (OP)
¿19 CCR § 2760.4 Training (TRN)
¿19 CCR § 2760.5 Mechanical Integrity (MI)
¿19 CCR § 2760.6 Management of Change (MOC)
¿19 CCR § 2760.7 Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)
¿19 CCR § 2760.8 Compliance Audits (CA)
¿19 CCR § 2760.9 Incident Investigation (II)
¿19 CCR § 2760.10 Employee Participation (EP)
¿19 CCR § 2760.11 Hot Work Permit (HWP)
¿19 CCR § 2760.12 Contractors (CON)

Five-Year Accident History
There have been no reportable releases of propane at the facility in at least the past five (5) years.

Emergency Response Program
The facility is included in the written Community Emergency Response Plan (ERP) and is a non-responding facility which has an Emergency Action Plan in place. The Emergency Action Plan details policies and procedures in the event of a dangerous situation such as: fire, earthquake, chemical hazards/propane leak, and terrorists' threats. A detailed Emergency Action Plan can be found in the program binder which specifies emergency numbers, evacuation procedures, emergency exits, and specific responses to individual hazards.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
